title: clubpro
text: clubpro implementation subset methods described Grice (2011) classification observations using binary procrustes rotation. Binary procrustes rotation can used quantify well observed data can classified known categories. high degree classification accuracy indicates ordering observed data well explained particular categories experimental conditions.

title: clubpro
text: clubpro can installed CRAN command install.packages("clubpro") loaded usual way. plots provided clubpro use colour palette loaded current R session. may specify plot colours passing vector colours palette().

what: Classifying catch location by jellyfish size
title: clubpro
text: Hand et. . (1994) provide data width length mm jellyfish caught two locations New South Wales, Australia: Dangar Island Salamander Bay. quantify well jellyfish width predicted catch location, binary procrustes rotation can performed clubpro passing formula object form observed variable ~ predictor variables(s) data.frame containing data club() function. two important statistics returned club() function percentage correct classifications (PCC), chance-value. PCC percenatge observations data classified correct category. PCC returned club() can accessed using pcc() function. chance-value computed using randomisation test determine frequently PCC least high computed observed ordering data found random reorderings data. Calling cval() function object returned club() shows chance-value model. Note chance-value computed using randomisation test, value slightly different time model run. detailed classification model results can returned using summary() function. Note values summary output rounded according digits argument summary defaults 2. classification observed data can visualised plotting model object using plot() function.  Plotting classification results shows observed width values 11 mm smaller consistently placed Dangar Island category, observed width values least 16.5 mm placed Salamader Bay category. results can see boundary two categories somewhere 11 16.5. However, clear plot exactly likely boundary falls. Grice et. al. (2016) suggest case binary classification, optimal category boundary can determined calculating PCC possible boundary location. can achieved using threshold() function. Plotting object returned threshold() shows three adjacent category boundary locations produce equal maximum PCCs. indicates optimal category boundary classification occurs 11 13 mm.  observation, classification strength index (CSI) 0 1 returned. value 1 indicates observed value matched perfectly rotation, whereas lower CSI values indicate observations matched less well. CSI values can accessed using csi() function, visualised plotting object returned call csi() function.  predicted categories determined model can tabulated using predict() function. case, 22 jellyfish caught Dangar Island, 17 classified come Dangar Island 5 classified come Salamander Bay. 24 jellyfish caught Salamander Bay, 2 classified come Dangar Island 22 correctly classified come Salamander Bay. predictions can visualised mosaic plot plotting object returned predict() function.  information can tabulated terms prediction accuracy using accuracy() function. predicted categories, prediction accuracy can also plotted form mosaic plot using plot(accuracy()).  calculation chance-value frequency occurance PCCs randomly reordered data least high PCC observed data ordering can visualised plotting output pcc_replicates() function. Calling plot() function output pcc_replicates() produces histogram PCCs resulting random orderings data. chance value calculated model frequency PCCs produced random reorderings data least high PCC produced observed data ordering, indicated plot dashed vertical line.
code: mod <- club(width ~ location, data = jellyfish) pcc(mod) #> [1] 84.78261 cval(mod) #> [1] 0.011 summary(mod) #> ********** Model Summary ********** #>  #> ----- Classification Results ----- #> Observations:  46  #> Missing observations:  0  #> Target groups:  2  #> Correctly classified observations:  39  #> Incorrectly classified observations:  7  #> Ambiguously classified observations:  0  #> PCC:  84.78  #> Median classification strength index:  1  #>  #> ----- Randomisation Test Results ----- #> Random reorderings:  1000  #> Minimum random PCC:  52.17  #> Maximum random PCC:  86.96  #> Chance-value:  0.01 plot(mod) threshold(mod) #>     obs      PCC #> 1   6.0 54.34783 #> 2   6.5 58.69565 #> 3   7.0 65.21739 #> 4   8.0 73.91304 #> 5   9.0 76.08696 #> 6  10.0 78.26087 #> 7  11.0 84.78261 #> 8  12.0 84.78261 #> 9  13.0 84.78261 #> 10 14.0 82.60870 #> 11 15.0 76.08696 #> 12 16.0 67.39130 #> 13 16.5 65.21739 #> 14 17.0 63.04348 #> 15 18.0 56.52174 #> 16 19.0 52.17391 #> 17 20.0 50.00000 plot(threshold(mod)) mod_csi <- csi(mod) plot(mod_csi) predict(mod) #>                  #>                  Dangar Island Salamander Bay #>   Dangar Island             17              5 #>   Salamander Bay             2             22 plot(predict(mod)) accuracy(mod) #>                  #>                  correct incorrect ambiguous #>   Dangar Island       17         5         0 #>   Salamander Bay      22         2         0 plot(accuracy(mod)) plot(pcc_replicates(mod))

title: clubpro
text: Grice, J. W. (2011). Observation oriented modeling: Analysis cause behavioral sciences. Academic Press. Grice, J. W., Cota, L. D., Barrett, P. T., Wuensch, K. L., & Poteat, G. M. (2016). Simple Transparent Alternative Logistic Regression. Advances Social Sciences Research Journal, 3(7), 147–165. Hand, D. J., Daly, F., Lunn, . D., McConway, K. J. Ostrowski, E. (1994). Handbook Small Data Sets. Chapman & Hall.

title: Classify observations. — club
text: club() used classify obervations using binary procrustes rotation.

title: Classify observations. — club
code: club(   f,   data,   imprecision,   nreps,   normalise_cols,   reorder_obs,   display_progress )

title: Classify observations. — club
text: f formula. data data.frame. imprecision number indicting margin imprecision allowed classification. nreps number replicates use randomisation test. normalise_cols boolean indicating whether normalise matrix columns. reorder_obs string indicating method reordering observations calculate c-values. display_progress boolean indictaing whether progress bar displayed.

title: Classify observations. — club
text: object class "clubprofit" list containing folllowing components: prediction character vector predicted classifications. accuracy character vector indicating whether classification   "correct", "incorrect", "ambiguous". pcc percentage correct classifications. cval chance randomly reordered data producing PCC >=   observed PCC. pcc_replicates vector PCCs generated randomly reordered   data used calculate cval. call matched call.

title: Compare models. — compare
code: m1 <- club(width ~ location, jellyfish) m2 <- club(length ~ location, jellyfish) compare(m1, m2) #> ********** Model Comparison ********** #> Absolute PCC difference:  8.7  #> Minimum random PCC difference:  -30.43  #> Maximum random PCC difference:  21.74  #> Chance-value:  0.19
